title: Nelly Armstrong: a story of the day. By the author of “Rose Douglas” [i.e. S. R. Whitehead]
author: Armstrong, Nelly.
snippet: It was easy to overlook her in the crowds; besides, she reflects that the girl by this time may be greatly changed. But it was sad to return every night to Danube Street, and her object not accomplished. Her mother too is agitated all the time of her absence, and sits counting the hours.

title: Nelly Armstrong: a story of the day. By the author of “Rose Douglas” [i.e. S. R. Whitehead]
author: Armstrong, Nelly.
snippet: They now proceeded in sUence, and soon reached Danube Street, which Nelly, who had dried up her tears, viewed with great approba-

title: Nelly Armstrong: a story of the day. By the author of “Rose Douglas” [i.e. S. R. Whitehead]
author: Armstrong, Nelly.
snippet: Her visits there did her much harm. They kept her in constant excitement, and disgusted her with the quiet way of Uving in Danube Street. Mrs. EUiot did not often

title: Nelly Armstrong: a story of the day. By the author of “Rose Douglas” [i.e. S. R. Whitehead]
author: Armstrong, Nelly.
snippet: Mrs. EUiot had little opportunity of observing NeUy's conduct for some weeks; her health was indifferent; and George had arrived in Danube Street. He had said fareweU to his parents, and was to proceed direct to London when he left Edinburgh.

title: Nelly Armstrong: a story of the day. By the author of “Rose Douglas” [i.e. S. R. Whitehead]
author: Armstrong, Nelly.
snippet: A few days after her return, Mrs. MaxweU Grey drove to Danube Street. Nelly had been warned by Janet to expect her, but she had not had courage to inform Mrs. EUiot that she intended leaving her service.

title: Nelly Armstrong: a story of the day. By the author of “Rose Douglas” [i.e. S. R. Whitehead]
author: Armstrong, Nelly.
snippet: pretty late. NeUy, when she went to bed, had pleasanter things to think of than the parting with the famdy in Danube Street.

title: Nelly Armstrong: a story of the day. By the author of “Rose Douglas” [i.e. S. R. Whitehead]
author: Armstrong, Nelly.
snippet: But again her companions talk dissipated the impression. They parted from her at the corner of Danube Street.

title: Nelly Armstrong: a story of the day. By the author of “Rose Douglas” [i.e. S. R. Whitehead]
author: Armstrong, Nelly.
snippet: Old Leezie the bowlwoman was a constant visitor of theirs. Leezie's basket and weU-patched cloak were most convenient receptacles for aU kinds of household stuff, empty bottles, &c. Twice a week she was sure to caU, not stealing cautiously down the area steps as formerly in Danube Street, but with a familiar and deliberate tread, as if she knew she was welcome.

title: Nelly Armstrong: a story of the day. By the author of “Rose Douglas” [i.e. S. R. Whitehead]
author: Armstrong, Nelly.
snippet: It was not that she thought of applying to her former mistress, but that she was most famiUar with that locality. StUl, though with no purpose, as I have said, she went straight on to Danube Street, but when she came to the entrance of it she paused. She looked wistfully along the little street towards Mrs. EUiot's house.

title: Nelly Armstrong: a story of the day. By the author of “Rose Douglas” [i.e. S. R. Whitehead]
author: Armstrong, Nelly.
snippet: Nelly, though a little shy at first, was soon encouraged by Miss EUiot's gentleness, and before they reached Danube Street had communicated to her almost aU her little history. She alluded gratefully to Miss Archer's kindness ; but when answering a question of the young lady's relating to her parents, the recollection of the sorrowful parting that morning, made her heart so very full that she could not go on.

title: Nelly Armstrong: a story of the day. By the author of “Rose Douglas” [i.e. S. R. Whitehead]
author: Armstrong, Nelly.
snippet: The " term" at length arrived, and NeUy went to her new situation. Before she left Danube Street, Mrs. EUiot gave her much good advice, which, for the time, produced a strong effect on that wayward but impressionable young person. She thought Mrs. EUiot a " saint for goodness," and promised again and again that she would not forget her warnings or aUow anything to tempt her to neglect her duty.

title: Nelly Armstrong: a story of the day. By the author of “Rose Douglas” [i.e. S. R. Whitehead]
author: Armstrong, Nelly.
snippet: The winter passed away with great quietness. NeUy had by this time almost forgot the former freedom she had enjoyed, and was considerably reconcUed to the sober ways of the family in Danube Street. She now took some pleasure in reading, and, under Martha's superintendence, promised fair to become a steady and valuable servant.

title: Nelly Armstrong: a story of the day. By the author of “Rose Douglas” [i.e. S. R. Whitehead]
author: Armstrong, Nelly.
snippet: They had been settled for a few days in their new home, a small but neat house in Danube Street, to which they had got entrance

title: Nelly Armstrong: a story of the day. By the author of “Rose Douglas” [i.e. S. R. Whitehead]
author: Armstrong, Nelly.
snippet: " Oh ! I'm wi' Mrs. EUiot in Danube Street;" said little NeUy with some dignity,
